EnglishScore: International students must meet the university’s English language proficiency requirements. Accepted tests for graduate students include TOEFL iBT (79 with subscores of 17+), IELTS (6.5 with subscores of 6.0+), PTE (58), Duolingo (110), or ELS Level 112.
Requirements: The application and all supporting documentation must be received by the application deadline. Admission decisions will not be made until all materials have been received. Successful applicants must meet the following requirements: 1. Bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited college or university. 2. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. Applicants with a GPA below 3.0 will be considered based on a holistic review of all application materials. 3. Completion of prerequisite courses with a C or better prior to admission. 4. Submit GMAT/GRE scores (may be waived). 5. Submit all application materials through the online graduate application: a. Online Application; b. Application Fee; c. Resume; d. Statement of Purpose; e. Two references; f. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended.
Department: College of Business
Description: Accountants are business professionals who prepare and analyze financial information for organizations of all types. An accounting degree prepares individuals to enter a career field that is very much in demand in all areas of the country and world. Accountants compile, categorize, interpret, and summarize financial data for use in analyzing and reporting on the financial position and operating performance of organizations. In addition to being responsible for maintaining accounting records and preparing financial statements, accountants perform a variety of related tasks, including: preparing tax forms, analyzing costs and revenues, auditing financial statements, and providing financial advice to individuals and organizations. Students earning a Bachelor of Science (BS) in Accounting will be prepared to work in public accounting, industry, government, or not-for-profit organizations. The accounting curriculum is designed to provide students with a broad business base and a strong accounting background including courses in financial accounting, managerial accounting, auditing, taxation, and accounting information systems. The coursework will provide a foundation for those students who wish to pursue professional certification such as the Certified Public Accountant (CPA) or Certified Management Accountant (CMA).
Accredidation: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
CostPerCredit: $316.45 per credit (MN Resident) + $25.00 per credit for upper-level (300-400) College of Business courses

Requirements: Must earn a "C" or better in all Accounting classes. An overall GPA of 2.5 is required in all Accounting courses. Business majors may not minor in Accounting.
Department: College of Business

Requirements: A 'C' (2.0) or better is required for all courses in the minor. This minor is open to all students and especially to students who major in Mathematics, Statistics, Finance, Accounting, Economics, or Computer Science.
Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology
Description: The minor in Actuarial Science is designed to prepare students for the demands of the actuarial profession. Students completing this minor will gain a strong foundation in mathematics, statistics, and finance, essential for passing professional actuarial examinations and pursuing a career in various fields such as insurance, risk management, and pensions. The curriculum emphasizes analytical skills, problem-solving techniques, and an understanding of financial instruments and markets. This minor complements a wide range of majors, including Mathematics, Statistics, Finance, and Economics, providing a valuable interdisciplinary perspective for students interested in a career as an actuary.

Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Advocating for Social Justice Minor provides students with knowledge, skills, and values to critically analyze structures of power and privilege, and to advocate for social justice in diverse contexts. The minor is interdisciplinary, drawing from fields such as sociology, psychology, political science, ethnic studies, gender and women's studies, and communication studies. Students will explore theoretical frameworks of social justice, engage in critical self-reflection, and develop practical skills for promoting equity and inclusion through activism, community organizing, and policy advocacy. The minor prepares students to address complex social issues such as inequality, discrimination, and human rights violations, and to contribute to positive social change.

Department: College of Education, Allied Health, and Nursing
Description: The Aeronautics Minor is open to all students and will provide knowledge of the various facets of aviation and aerospace. This includes topics in aviation history, fundamentals of flight, air traffic control, aviation safety, navigation, and human factors. The minor can be taken by students who are interested in aviation and provides a broad base of knowledge in Aeronautics.

ProgramName: Aging Studies for Nursing Students Minor
Requirements: This interdisciplinary undergraduate minor in aging studies is open to nursing students at Minnesota State University, Mankato.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: This minor is designed for nursing students to enhance knowledge and skills in aging and prepare for careers working with older adults. The minor consists of courses from multiple disciplines on campus to provide a breadth of knowledge and understanding on various aspects of aging. These courses provide nursing students with a deeper understanding of the aging process, common health challenges in older adults, and strategies for providing high-quality, person-centered care. The minor enhances the nursing curriculum by offering specialized knowledge in gerontology, preparing graduates to excel in diverse healthcare settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, home healthcare, and community-based programs. Overall, the minor in Aging Studies for Nursing Students aims to equip future nurses with the expertise and sensitivity required to meet the unique needs of the growing older adult population, fostering compassionate and effective care.

Department: College of Social and Behavioral Sciences
Description: The Aging Studies minor provides students from a variety of disciplines with a multidisciplinary perspective on the aging process and older adults, focusing on the social, psychological, and biological aspects of aging. The minor is designed to complement most major fields of study and helps students prepare for career opportunities in the growing field of aging, as well as for further graduate study.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency. Accepted tests and minimum scores include TOEFL iBT: 61 (no subscore below 15), TOEFL PBT: 500, IELTS: 6.0 (no subscore below 5.0), Duolingo: 100, PTE Academic: 47, or completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: To gain admission, you'll need to complete the Minnesota State High School Preparation Requirements and meet our admission requirements. Minnesota State Mankato considers your high school GPA in addition to other context you might provide in your application. The application process involves completing the online application, paying the non-refundable $20 application fee, and submitting your official high school transcript. ACT/SAT scores are not required for admission.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Agribusiness and Food Innovation program at Minnesota State University, Mankato provides students with the business and technical skills necessary to meet the increasing demand for professionals in the food, agribusiness, and agricultural sectors. As the global population grows and consumer preferences evolve, the need for well-trained individuals who understand both the business aspects and the innovative practices within the food supply chain becomes critical. This program offers a unique blend of business administration principles, food science, and agricultural innovation, preparing students for dynamic careers in an essential global industry. Graduates will be equipped to tackle challenges related to food production, processing, distribution, marketing, and policy, while also driving innovation to create sustainable and efficient food systems. The curriculum emphasizes experiential learning through internships, case studies, and industry projects, ensuring students gain practical experience alongside theoretical knowledge. Our faculty, with diverse expertise in agribusiness, food science, and economics, are committed to fostering a learning environment that encourages critical thinking, problem-solving, and leadership development.

Requirements: The Agribusiness and Food Innovation minor is open to any student at Minnesota State University, Mankato.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing and College of Business
Description: The Agribusiness and Food Innovation minor provides students with knowledge and skills to understand the growing global food system and the essential role of agribusiness in providing food, fiber, and fuel. The curriculum provides a foundation in business management, economics, and marketing principles as they apply to the agricultural and food industries. It also emphasizes innovation, sustainability, and entrepreneurship within the food supply chain. This minor is open to all students, particularly those interested in careers in food production, distribution, marketing, and policy.

EnglishScore: For international undergraduate applicants, English proficiency can be demonstrated by meeting one of the following minimum requirements: TOEFL iBT score of 61, IELTS score of 5.5, Duolingo English Test score of 95, PTE Academic score of 47, or successful completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: To be considered for admission, you will need to submit: Completed online application. Official high school transcript (or GED scores). Non-refundable $20 application fee.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Sciences provides a broad-based curriculum leading to a variety of careers in agriculture. Students gain knowledge and skills in agribusiness, agricultural education, and agronomy, as well as a strong foundation in the sciences. The program emphasizes hands-on learning, research opportunities, and practical application of agricultural principles. Graduates are prepared for roles in agricultural business, production, education, research, and government.

Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Agriculture minor is designed for students who want to learn more about food production, sustainable agriculture, and the business of agriculture, but are pursuing a major in a different field. This minor allows students to explore various aspects of agriculture, including plant science, animal science, agricultural economics, and environmental sustainability. It provides a foundational understanding of agricultural principles and practices, preparing students for careers or further study in agriculture-related fields.

EnglishScore: International applicants must meet the university's English proficiency admission standards. Minimum scores for undergraduate admission include TOEFL iBT: 61, IELTS: 5.5, PTE: 47, or Duolingo: 95.
Requirements: As this is an undergraduate program, admission is governed by the university's general undergraduate admission requirements. To be considered for admission, you will need: Graduation from a high school or equivalent. Meet the college course preparation requirements.
Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology
Description: The Bachelor of Science degree in Agronomy provides students with knowledge and skills to sustainably manage plants and soils for crop production. Through courses and experiential learning opportunities, students will learn to assess and improve soil health, identify and manage plant diseases and pests, implement nutrient management plans, and utilize precision agriculture technologies. Graduates are prepared for careers in various sectors, including crop consulting, seed production, agricultural research, soil conservation, and farm management. This program is offered on campus at Minnesota State University, Mankato. The program is part of the Department of Agriscience & Food Innovations, located in the College of Science, Engineering and Technology.

EnglishScore: All applicants, regardless of citizenship, must demonstrate English language proficiency. Acceptable forms of evidence of English proficiency include official TOEFL, IELTS, PTE Academic, ELS, or Duolingo scores, or if the applicant has earned a bachelor's degree or higher from a regionally accredited U.S. college/university.
Requirements: Formal application to the Alcohol and Drug Studies (ADS) program is required for all students seeking a major or minor in ADS. Students must complete the online application for admission to the ADS program, including a statement of purpose and two letters of recommendation. Students who do not meet these standards may petition the ADS Program Committee for admission. Admission into the Alcohol and Drug Studies (ADS) major or minor will be determined using the following criteria: Completion of HLTH 101 or equivalent with a grade of "C" or better. Overall GPA of 2.5 or above. Completion of the Online Application. Submission of a 500-word statement of purpose. Submission of two letters of recommendation.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degree in Alcohol and Drug Studies prepares students to become licensed alcohol and drug counselors. The program curriculum is designed to meet Minnesota licensure requirements for alcohol and drug counselors and includes coursework in pharmacology, physiology, assessment and diagnosis, ethics, counseling theories, and group counseling. Students gain valuable practical experience through a supervised internship placement in a chemical dependency treatment facility. Graduates are prepared for employment in a variety of settings, including inpatient and outpatient treatment centers, correctional facilities, and community-based agencies. The Alcohol and Drug Studies program is accredited by the Minnesota Board of Behavioral Health and Therapy (BBHT).
Accredidation: Accredited by the Minnesota Board of Behavioral Health and Therapy (BBHT)

Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The minor in Alcohol and Drug Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to prepare students for professional positions in the treatment and prevention of alcohol and drug abuse, and to enhance career options for individuals majoring in other areas such as social work, criminal justice, nursing, psychology, corrections, and health. The minor also provides an excellent foundation for graduate education related to chemical dependency work or other related fields.

EnglishScore: For international applicants, proof of English proficiency is required. This can be demonstrated by achieving a minimum score on one of the following tests: TOEFL iBT (79), IELTS (6.0), Duolingo (110), or PTE (53). Completion of ELS Level 112 also satisfies this requirement.
Requirements: First-year admission to Minnesota State University, Mankato is based on a review of your high school record. Admission is guaranteed if you have a cumulative high school GPA of 3.0 or higher OR you have a cumulative high school GPA of 2.7 or higher AND rank in the top 50% of your high school class. If you don't meet the primary review criteria, we will conduct a comprehensive review of your application. The comprehensive review process includes the following factors: High school coursework, GPA, class rank, ACT/SAT test scores (if provided), Personal statement, Extracurricular activities and work experience.
Department: College of Social and Behavioral Sciences
Description: American Indigenous Studies (AIS) is an interdisciplinary program designed for students who wish to learn about the histories, cultures, politics, and contemporary experiences of Indigenous peoples in North America and globally. AIS prepares students to work with tribal nations, Indigenous communities, and organizations, as well as in fields such as education, law, social work, public policy, environmental studies, and museum studies. The program offers a minor and also provides a valuable complement to a wide range of majors including but not limited to Ethnic Studies, History, Political Science, Sociology, Anthropology, English, and Social Work.

EnglishScore: All international students must provide proof of English proficiency. Scores must be sent directly from the testing agency to Minnesota State University, Mankato (school code 6677). This requirement can be met by providing one of the following: TOEFL: 61 iBT, IELTS: 5.5, PTE Academic: 42, Duolingo: 95, Successful completion of Minnesota State University, Mankato's Intensive English Program (IEP), or Successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112.
Requirements:
Applicants must meet the admission requirements of the College of Graduate Studies and Research. In addition, the following is required for admission to the Anthropology MA program:

Three Letters of Recommendation. From people familiar with the student's academic abilities (e.g., faculty from undergraduate institution). Letters should address the student's potential for success in a graduate program.
A 500-1000 word Statement of Purpose. The statement should address the student's interests in anthropology and how those interests can be addressed by this program.
A Writing Sample. An undergraduate paper is preferred.
A resume or CV.
A baccalaureate degree from an accredited university. While most applicants will have an undergraduate degree in anthropology, students with other undergraduate majors are encouraged to apply. The department may require students to take undergraduate anthropology courses to correct deficiencies.
A minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: Anthropology is the study of people, past and present. It is a broad discipline that seeks to understand the human condition, from the origins of humankind to the diversity of cultures around the world. The Anthropology program at Minnesota State University, Mankato is designed to provide students with a comprehensive understanding of the major subfields of anthropology: cultural anthropology, archaeology, biological anthropology, and linguistic anthropology. Students will develop critical thinking skills, research abilities, and a global perspective, preparing them for a variety of careers or for further graduate studies.

Department: College of Social and Behavioral Sciences
Description: Anthropology is the systematic study of humanity throughout time and the world. Anthropology is a broad, holistic, and global discipline. Students will learn the interrelationship between social life, human biology, culture, and the environment. Anthropology is considered a social science, but it also has strong links to the humanities and natural sciences. A minor in Anthropology provides a rich foundation for understanding human diversity for students interested in a variety of careers and fields. Students will learn how to approach the human experience by using four different but related areas, including: cultural anthropology, physical anthropology, archaeology, and linguistic anthropology. The Anthropology minor is useful for students interested in careers related to cultural resource management, museums, forensic science, international relations, social justice, law, public health, medicine, education, public policy, marketing, and social research.

EnglishScore: Students from non-English speaking countries must provide proof of English proficiency. Minnesota State University, Mankato accepts TOEFL iBT score of 79 or higher, TOEFL PBT score of 550 or higher, IELTS overall score of 6.0 or higher, Duolingo English Test score of 110 or higher, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic score of 53 or higher, or successful completion of level 112 at an ELS Language Center.
Requirements: High school GPA is the primary factor in the admission review process. Students are encouraged to submit an ACT or SAT score if they feel it will strengthen their application. Students with a cumulative high school GPA of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale) will be offered admission to Minnesota State Mankato. Students with a cumulative high school GPA between 2.70 and 2.99 (on a 4.0 scale) will be considered for admission based on a holistic review of their application. Students with a cumulative high school GPA below a 2.7 (on a 4.0 scale) will be considered for admission based on a holistic review of their application, and are strongly encouraged to submit an ACT/SAT score and/or a personal statement to strengthen their application.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Concentration: Health Science, Pre-Physician Assistant, and Pre-Physical Therapy
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Applied Health Science provides a flexible program of study for individuals interested in health-related careers. This degree is designed to articulate with the Minnesota State A.S. in Exercise Science, Health Sciences Broad Field, or Human Services degrees. Students with other A.S. degrees or significant transfer credits may be admitted to the program on a case-by-case basis. This program offers three concentrations related to allied health: Health Science, Pre-Physician Assistant, and Pre-Physical Therapy. Graduates from the Applied Health Science program are prepared to enter graduate programs in fields such as physical therapy, physician assistant, occupational therapy, chiropractic, public health, health administration, athletic training, clinical exercise physiology, and other allied health professions. Some graduates will also pursue careers in fields such as fitness, personal training, community health, and health education. This program is offered in both on-campus and online formats.
ScholarshipAmount: Amounts range from $500 to more than $10,000
ScholarshipType: Academic, diversity, leadership, talent-based, departmental, financial need-based

Requirements: An Applied Health Science Minor is available to any student.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Applied Health Science Minor provides an interdisciplinary and applied perspective for students interested in a variety of health related areas including health promotion, disease prevention, physical activity, and sport. Students who complete this minor will be able to analyze and apply health behavior theories, communicate effectively using diverse health topics, promote and assess physically active lifestyles, and identify and utilize evidence-based health resources. The minor will offer students a foundation in health sciences that can be applied to many professions or as a foundation for graduate study in a variety of health-related fields.

EnglishScore: International Students: must have a bachelor’s degree that is equivalent to a U.S. bachelor’s degree. To find out if your degree is equivalent, please visit the ECE (Educational Credential Evaluators) website at www.ece.org or WES (World Education Services) at www.wes.org for a course by course evaluation. We also require a test of English proficiency. More information for international students is available at www.mnsu.edu/international. The university's general graduate requirements include TOEFL score of 79 iBT, IELTS score of 6.5, PTE Academic score of 53, or Duolingo English Test score of 110.
Requirements:
Applicants seeking admission to the Master of Science in Applied Leadership program must submit the following materials to the College of Graduate Studies:

1. A completed application for graduate study.
2. A current resume.
3. Official transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended. Applicants must have a minimum of a 2.75 GPA.
4. A letter of application intent/goal statement explaining your interest in the program and your personal and professional goals (not to exceed 500 words).
5. Two professional letters of recommendation.
Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Minor in Applied Leadership is designed for students from all majors who want to learn leadership theories and apply them to their personal and professional lives. The Minor provides students with critical thinking, problem solving, decision making, team development, organizational change, and communication skills necessary for effectively leading and managing others in diverse environments. Students also learn how to identify their own leadership strengths and areas for growth to become impactful and ethical leaders. The Minor will provide an excellent complement to any major and will enhance students’ marketability for employment and further education.

EnglishScore: International graduate applicants must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following: a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 79 (with a minimum of 17 on speaking and 17 on writing), a minimum IELTS score of 6.0 (with no subscore below 5.5), a minimum Duolingo English Test score of 110, a minimum Pearson Test of English (PTE) score of 53, or have completed ELS Level 112.
Requirements: In addition to the requirements of the College of Graduate Studies and Research, the Department of Art and Design has the following admission requirements: 1. A portfolio of twenty images of recent work. 2. A one-page statement of intent which addresses the applicant's background, influences, and current direction. 3. Three letters of recommendation from former instructors or other qualified people. 4. Transcripts from all previous colleges and universities. 5. A curriculum vitae or resume.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Studio Art degree provides students with a broad and rigorous exposure to various art media and theoretical issues. Students will learn how to analyze and critically evaluate works of art from multiple cultural perspectives. The program will enhance their understanding of art and its context and prepare them for careers in art-related fields or for graduate study.

Department: College of Arts and Humanities
Description: The Art & Design minor introduces students to the visual arts and prepares them for future work or graduate study in a variety of art related fields. Upon completion of the Art & Design Minor, students will be able to: Utilize creative design thinking skills in the process of art production. Critique and analyze artworks using appropriate art and design terminology. Describe the history and theory of art and design within diverse cultural contexts. Articulate aesthetic and philosophical concepts in visual art through written and oral presentations.

EnglishScore: International students may demonstrate English proficiency in several ways, including: TOEFL iBT score of 61, IELTS score of 5.5, Duolingo score of 95, PTE Academic score of 47, or ELS completion of level 112.
Requirements: Admission to the College of Graduate Studies. A four-year baccalaureate degree from a regionally accredited college or university. A grade point average of at least 3.00 (B) on a 4.00 scale for the last two years of undergraduate work. For non-native English speakers an English Proficiency Test is required (see Graduate Catalog for more information). Department application requirements (submitted online): Statement of intent: a 500-1000 word statement outlining the applicant’s academic background, interest in the program, and research goals. Official Transcripts. Letters of Recommendation: 3 letters of recommendation from individuals familiar with the applicant’s academic and/or artistic potential. Resume/Curriculum Vitae. Writing sample: 10-15 page writing sample on an art history, theory, or criticism topic.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Art History program provides students with the critical thinking, communication, and research skills necessary to analyze art and its historical and cultural contexts. The curriculum offers students a wide range of courses and topics from the ancient world to contemporary art. Through a combination of required and elective courses, students gain a comprehensive understanding of various art movements, styles, and theories. Students will also learn to interpret visual culture, articulate ideas through written and oral presentations, and conduct independent research. The program prepares students for careers in museums, galleries, archives, higher education, arts administration, or for graduate study in art history or related fields.

Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: Welcome to the Art History Program at Minnesota State University, Mankato. We offer a challenging curriculum in the history of art and architecture, from antiquity to the contemporary period, taught by faculty who are active in research and scholarship. In the classroom, you will learn to hone your skills in visual analysis, critical thinking, research, and writing. Outside of the classroom, you will have opportunities to visit museums and galleries, participate in campus events and art organizations, complete internships, and travel abroad. If you wish to declare a major or minor in Art History or simply have questions about the program, please contact a faculty member or the Department Chair.

EnglishScore: International students must prove English language proficiency through one of the following options: a score of 61 on the Internet-based TOEFL (iBT) or 500 on the paper-based TOEFL (PBT); 5.5 on the IELTS; 42 on the Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic; 95 on the Duolingo English Test; or successful completion of Level 112 at an ELS Language Center. Other options for demonstrating proficiency are also available, such as SAT/ACT scores or graduating from a high school in the United States.
Requirements: Admission to the Professional Education sequence requires a formal application that is typically submitted during the sophomore year. The basic requirements for admission include: 1. A cumulative GPA of 2.75 or higher. 2. Completion of specific courses with a grade of 'C' or better (see department). 3. Passing scores on a state-approved basic skills test (e.g., ACT, SAT, MTLE, or Accuplacer Reading/Writing).
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts degree with an emphasis in Art Teaching K-12 is designed to prepare students for a Minnesota teaching license in Visual Arts (K-12). The program prepares students to teach visual art effectively to a wide range of students in diverse settings. Students develop knowledge and skills in art media, art history, art criticism, and aesthetics, and apply these within effective teaching methodologies. Students cultivate an understanding of learners, content knowledge, instructional practices, and professional dispositions required of successful teachers. The curriculum provides a strong studio art foundation and a comprehensive understanding of current practices in art education. Graduates will be prepared to teach art to children and adolescents in public and private schools.

Requirements: 20 credits. Students minoring in Astronomy must earn a C or better in all courses taken for the minor.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: The Astronomy Minor provides students with an in-depth understanding of the physical processes governing the universe. This minor is an excellent complement to majors in Physics, Chemistry, Geology, and Computer Science, providing a broader scientific perspective and analytical skills applicable to a wide range of careers in science, technology, and education. Students will explore topics such as celestial mechanics, stellar evolution, galaxies, cosmology, and observational astronomy through a combination of theoretical study and hands-on experience using telescopes and astronomical data analysis tools.

Department: College of Allied Health and Nursing
Description: The Athletic Coaching Minor is designed to prepare students for coaching positions at the youth, interscholastic, and intercollegiate levels. The 18-credit minor provides students with the foundational knowledge and skills necessary to effectively lead and develop athletes, encompassing areas such as sport psychology, exercise physiology, motor learning, and coaching methodology. It is suitable for students pursuing various majors who wish to combine their primary field of study with a credential in athletic coaching.

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must demonstrate English proficiency by submitting one of the following: TOEFL (61 iBT or 500 PBT), IELTS (5.5), Duolingo English Test (95), PTE Academic (47), or completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: Minnesota State Mankato reviews first-year applicants based on their high school GPA, courses taken in high school, and ACT or SAT score. To qualify for assured admission, you must meet one of the following criteria: Cumulative high school GPA of 3.0 or higher OR High school GPA between 2.70-2.99 AND an ACT score of 21/SAT of 1060 or higher OR Rank in the top 50% of your high school class AND an ACT score of 21/SAT of 1060 or higher. Students who do not meet the assured admission criteria are still encouraged to apply and will be reviewed through a holistic review process that considers multiple factors. Minnesota State Mankato is currently test-optional, meaning an ACT or SAT is not required for admission.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: A minor in Automotive Engineering Technology will provide students with the foundational understanding of automotive systems, vehicle design, development, and manufacturing. This minor will broaden the student’s understanding of automotive systems for careers in the transportation field.

EnglishScore: All international applicants must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be met by providing ONE of the following: TOEFL: A minimum score of 61 iBT. IELTS: A minimum score of 5.5. Duolingo: A minimum score of 95. PTE Academic: A minimum score of 47. ELS Language Center: Completion of level 112.
Requirements: Professional Pilot training is limited to 25 students per semester. Admission into the professional flight program is on a competitive basis. Criteria considered include: Cumulative GPA, Aviation Related Course GPA, Interview with Aviation Faculty/Staff, Previous flight experience, Written essay (prompt provided at interview), Letters of recommendation (1 minimum).
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Fees: In addition to university tuition, estimated flight training costs are approximately $88,000 for the Professional Flight major.
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Aviation prepares students for diverse careers within the aviation industry. Three options allow students to choose areas of specialization including Aviation Management, Flight, or Maintenance Management. The Aviation Management option prepares students for professional positions in airport management, air transportation, government agencies, and other aviation-related businesses. The Flight option prepares students for careers as professional pilots within the commercial, corporate, and airline industries. The Maintenance Management option prepares students for careers in aircraft maintenance management, including commercial airline maintenance, corporate aviation maintenance, repair stations, and fixed base operations. Graduates of this program will possess the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute to and lead in various sectors of the aviation industry, ensuring safety, efficiency, and innovation. The program emphasizes a strong foundation in aviation principles, regulations, and operations, complemented by practical experience and specialized knowledge relevant to their chosen option.
Accredidation: Accredited by Aviation Accreditation Board International (AABI).
CollegeApplicationFee: In addition to university tuition, estimated flight training costs are approximately $88,000 for the Professional Flight major.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by scholarship, with examples of $1,000 and $1,500 awards.

Requirements:
The Aviation minor offers undergraduate students who are majoring in other fields the opportunity to acquire a basic understanding of the air transportation industry. Coursework provides a basic understanding of the National Airspace System, aviation industry, and airport management. 19-20 credits are required for this minor.

Required Courses (13 credits):
AVIA 101 Intro to Aviation (3)
AVIA 205 Private Pilot Flying I (2)
AVIA 220 FAA Regulations (3)
AVIA 230 Aircraft Systems (3)
AVIA 240 Aerodynamics (2)

Electives (6-7 credits):
Students must complete a minimum of 6 credits from the following courses:
AVIA 300W Aviation Safety (3)
AVIA 305 Private Pilot Flying II (2)
AVIA 315 Instrument Pilot Flying I (2)
AVIA 325 Instrument Pilot Flying II (2)
AVIA 330 Air Traffic Control Sys (3)
AVIA 335 Human Factors (3)
AVIA 350 Aviation Law (3)
AVIA 375 Corporate Aviation Mgmt (3)
AVIA 425 Airline Operations (3)
AVIA 435 Airport Management (3)
AVIA 455 Aviation Internship (1-12)
Department: College of Education
Description: The Aviation Minor is intended to provide students from any major with introductory knowledge of the aviation industry and the technical skills associated with private pilot certification. The minor provides a foundation for students interested in careers in aviation, either as a professional pilot, or in other aviation related fields, while also allowing students to receive academic credit for flight training. All flight training and ground instruction is provided by the MSU, Mankato Department of Aviation. All students completing the minor will earn their Private Pilot Certificate through the courses included in the minor curriculum.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies, with specific awards for aviation students such as $1,000 or $2,500 available.

EnglishScore: Proof of English proficiency is required for international students. Accepted tests and minimum scores for graduate students include: TOEFL iBT score of 79 (with a minimum score of 17 on the speaking and writing sections), IELTS score of 6.5, PTE Academic score of 58, Duolingo English Test score of 110, or successful completion of ELS Level 112 Intensive Program.
Requirements: Admission to the Major: Students must have a grade of C- or better in CHEM 201.
Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology
Description: Biochemistry is an interdisciplinary major with the goal of preparing students for careers in fields related to chemistry and biology (biotechnology, forensics, medicine, pharmacy, veterinary medicine, environmental chemistry, and related sciences). A degree in biochemistry also prepares students for graduate studies in biochemistry, molecular biology, and other related health sciences. The biochemistry curriculum combines a strong foundation in chemistry and biology with laboratory experience. Our faculty are experts in a wide variety of chemical and biological disciplines, including forensic chemistry, analytical chemistry, computational chemistry, microbiology, organic synthesis, biochemistry, and plant biology.

EnglishScore: International applicants must submit an official score from at least one of the following exams: TOEFL iBT: 79 (with minimum subscores: writing 20, speaking 20); IELTS: 6.5 (with minimum subscores: writing 6.0, speaking 6.0); PTE Academic: 58; Duolingo English Test: 110; ELS: Completion of ELS Level 112 with a grade of B or higher.
Requirements: In order to be considered for admission, first-year applicants must submit the following: 1. Completed application. 2. $20 non-refundable application fee. 3. Official high school transcript. Minnesota State Mankato is test-optional, which means you can choose whether or not to submit your ACT or SAT scores as part of your application.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: The Bachelor of Arts in Biology is designed for students desiring a flexible program in Biology. It is appropriate for pre-professional students interested in such areas as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, optometry, and veterinary medicine. Students may also combine this degree with a minor in Chemistry or other related field. Since this degree provides a broad background in Biology, it is also suitable for students planning to continue their education in graduate school or those who plan to teach at the secondary level after obtaining the appropriate education licensure.

Requirements: A minimum of 22 credits with a minimum GPA of 2.0 in the minor courses is required. A grade of "C-" or better is required for all minor courses.
Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology

EnglishScore: International applicants are required to provide proof of English proficiency. Acceptable tests and minimum scores include TOEFL iBT (79), IELTS (6.5), PTE (53), Duolingo (110), or completion of ELS Level 112. Applicants from certain English-speaking countries may be exempt.
Requirements: To be admitted to the university, freshman applicants must meet one of the following criteria: Rank in the top 50% of your high school class, OR Earn a 3.0 GPA (on a 4.0 scale), OR Score 21 or higher on the ACT (1060 or higher on the SAT). Minnesota State Mankato does not require an ACT or SAT score for admission. For admission to the Professional Education Sequence, which is required for this program, candidates need an overall GPA of 2.75, completion of specific courses with a grade of C or better, passing scores on a basic skills exam approved by the MN Professional Educator Licensing and Standards Board (PELSB), approval by the department, a formal application, and completion of a background check.
Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology

EnglishScore: All applicants for graduate study whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. This can be demonstrated by one of the following: a score of 79 on the internet-based TOEFL (iBT) with a minimum score of 17 on the speaking and writing sections; or a score of 550 on the paper-based TOEFL (PBT); a score of 6.5 on the IELTS exam; a score of 53 on the Pearson's Test of English (PTE) Academic exam; a score of 110 on the Duolingo English Test; or successful completion of ELS Language Centers level 112.
Requirements: Baccalaureate degree in the biological sciences or a related area from a regionally accredited university. An overall undergraduate GPA of at least 3.0 (4.0 scale). Submitted scores for the Graduate Record Examination (GRE) general test. A minimum score of 144 on the quantitative portion of the test is required. There is no minimum required score for the verbal or analytical writing portions of the test. International applicants must also submit an official score from an English language proficiency examination (TOEFL or IELTS). See the College of Graduate Studies and Research website for minimum scores. Two letters of recommendation from individuals in a position to judge the student's potential for graduate study. Letters should be sent directly from the recommender to the graduate program coordinator. A Statement of Purpose written by the applicant and submitted with the application that indicates their area(s) of interest and career goals, as well as an explanation of why they are interested in the Minnesota State University, Mankato Biotechnology program. The statement should be 1 to 2 pages in length.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: Biotechnology is a rapidly expanding field of study that encompasses the application of living organisms and their components for the benefit of humankind. This interdisciplinary major will provide students with a strong foundation in the basic sciences of biology and chemistry and their applications in areas such as agriculture, medicine, bioremediation, and industrial applications. This degree prepares students for careers in the biotechnology industry, as well as for graduate study in biotechnology and related fields. Students completing the degree will have the opportunity to engage in cutting-edge research through laboratory courses and/or independent research projects.

EnglishScore: International applicants must demonstrate English proficiency through one of the following: TOEFL iBT minimum score of 61, IELTS minimum score of 5.5, Duolingo minimum score of 95, PTE Academic minimum score of 47, or successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112.
Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must have a bachelor's degree from a regionally accredited college or university with a cumulative GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. A current resume detailing professional work experience is required. Submission of GMAT or GRE scores is optional. Applicants whose native language is not English must submit TOEFL or IELTS scores. The GMAT/GRE is not required for applicants with a 3.2 cumulative undergraduate GPA and at least one of the following: three years of professional work experience, a graduate degree from a regionally accredited US college or university, or having passed a US professional licensure exam.
Department: College of Business
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Business Administration program offers a broad-based business education focused on developing the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute to the success of an organization. This program provides a solid foundation in the functional areas of business, including accounting, finance, marketing, management, and information systems. Students develop critical thinking, problem-solving, communication, and leadership skills essential for a dynamic business environment. The curriculum is designed to prepare graduates for a wide range of entry-level professional positions in various industries or for further graduate studies.
Accredidation: The College of Business is accredited by AACSB International – The Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business.
CostPerCredit: $326.65/credit, plus a $48.25/credit differential for 300/400 level courses

Requirements: This minor is available to any student not majoring in Business Administration, Finance, International Business, Management or Marketing. This minor does not qualify a student for admission into the College of Business upper-division courses. Prerequisites must be completed prior to taking courses in the minor.
Department: College of Business
Description: This interdisciplinary minor provides students from any major with a basic understanding of business, its language, and the functional areas within business. The minor provides fundamental knowledge about business and is especially useful for students in fields such as health care, arts, science, and education who anticipate working in or with organizations that are profit-oriented or that apply business principles. Students completing this minor will be better prepared to enter graduate programs in business or related fields. Completion of this minor provides fundamental knowledge about business and is especially useful for students in fields such as health care, arts, science, and education who anticipate working in or with organizations that are profit-oriented or that apply business principles.

Department: College of Business
Description: The Business Law Minor enhances any major with a strong foundation in business law. Students will gain an understanding of the legal environment of business, the structure of contracts, the principles of business organization, and various contemporary topics relating to the law. Students from any major are encouraged to consider a Business Law Minor.

EnglishScore: All international applicants must show proof of English proficiency. This can be met by submitting one of the following minimum test scores or successful completion of a program.
Requirements: To be admitted to the Business Teacher Education Program, a student must have: A declared major in Business Teaching (5-12) BS, An overall GPA of 2.75, Completed ENG 101 College Composition (4) and CMST 102 Public Speaking (3) or approved equivalents with a grade of 'C' or better, and Met the Minnesota Teacher Licensure Examinations (MTLE) Basic Skills requirement.
Department: College of Business

EnglishScore: Applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. Accepted options include TOEFL iBT (minimum score 61), IELTS (minimum score 6.0), PTE Academic (minimum score 43), Duolingo English Test (minimum score 100), or successful completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements: In addition to the general requirements for admission to the College of Graduate Studies and Research, applicants for admission to the Master of Science program in Chemistry are expected to have a minimum undergraduate grade point average of 3.00 (4.00 scale). Students must also have completed a bachelor's degree in chemistry or a related science that would include a minimum of one year each of general chemistry, organic chemistry, and physics, as well as one semester of analytical chemistry and one semester of physical chemistry. Students who do not meet these requirements may be admitted on a provisional basis, and will be required to complete the necessary prerequisite coursework. Application must include a brief (1-2 pages) statement of purpose describing their reasons for pursuing a graduate degree in chemistry, their career goals, and the name(s) of faculty with whom they are interested in conducting research. Application must also include a CV/resume and transcripts from all post-secondary institutions attended.
Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology
Concentration: ACS Certified, Biochemistry, Chemical Education, Forensic Chemistry
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Chemistry provides students with a strong background in analytical, biochemistry, inorganic, organic and physical chemistry. The BS degree is appropriate for students planning to pursue graduate studies in chemistry or biochemistry, or those seeking employment in chemical, pharmaceutical, biotechnological or other science-related industries. Students are prepared for a variety of careers including industrial chemist, research chemist, pharmaceutical chemist, forensic chemist, and materials scientist. Graduates are also prepared for pre-professional programs in medicine, dentistry, veterinary medicine, pharmacy, or other allied health fields. The BS degree in chemistry offers four concentrations: ACS Certified, Biochemistry, Chemical Education, Forensic Chemistry.

Requirements:
22 total credits required.

Required Courses:
CHEM 201 General Chemistry I (4)
CHEM 202 General Chemistry II (4)
CHEM 320 Quantitative Analysis (4)
CHEM 350 Organic Chemistry I (4)
CHEM 360 Organic Chemistry II (4)

CHEM Elective (2)
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: The minor in Chemistry offers students the opportunity to learn fundamental concepts in chemistry beyond the general education courses. This minor provides a solid foundation for students interested in careers where chemical principles are used and can be paired with any major. Students completing this minor will take courses in general and organic chemistry, along with additional chemistry electives. The minor provides a strong science background for students going into health care professions, forensic science, engineering, and other science-related fields.

EnglishScore: All applicants whose native language is not English must provide proof of English proficiency. This requirement can be met through approved test scores such as TOEFL (61 iBT or 500 PBT), IELTS (5.5), Duolingo (95), or PTE (47), or through other means like completion of the university's Intensive English Program or specific coursework.
Requirements: Minnesota State Mankato practices holistic review, which means we look at your academic record, and the rigor of your high school courses. Generally, we are looking for students who are in the top 50 percent of their high school class, have a GPA of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale), or have a composite score of 21 or higher on the ACT (1060 on the SAT).
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: This track is designed to provide students with a solid background in all areas of chemistry while also meeting the requirements for licensure to teach chemistry in Minnesota high schools. Students pursuing this track will gain a deep understanding of chemical principles and develop the pedagogical skills necessary to effectively teach chemistry concepts to secondary school students.

EnglishScore: All international students are required to demonstrate English proficiency. This can be met with a TOEFL iBT score of 61, IELTS score of 5.5, PTE Academic score of 42, Duolingo English Test (DET) score of 95, or completion of ELS Level 112 Intensive English Program, among other options.
Requirements: Students must complete the pre-professional courses with C or better in all courses and a 2.7 GPA in the required mathematics and science courses. Students apply for admission to the professional program through the department after completing these pre-professional courses. Students meeting these requirements are not guaranteed admission into the CE program.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: The Civil Engineering program prepares students to become professional engineers. Civil engineers design and build infrastructure that supports society and impacts the quality of life. Infrastructure systems include buildings, bridges, dams, airports, highways, water treatment, wastewater treatment, and solid waste management. The program is developed to provide a strong background in engineering fundamentals, civil engineering design, project management, and related engineering applications. The curriculum includes courses in a broad range of civil engineering areas, including structural engineering, environmental engineering, geotechnical engineering, transportation engineering, and water resources engineering. Students complete design projects in several courses. The program emphasizes ethical, social, and environmental responsibility, professional development, and the importance of lifelong learning. Graduates are prepared for a diverse range of civil engineering careers in consulting, government, and industry.
Accredidation: The BS Civil Engineering Program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $500 to $6,000 per year

Requirements: Required application materials for general undergraduate admission include the application for admission, a $20 non-refundable application fee, and an official high school transcript. Minnesota State Mankato is test-optional, which means that ACT/SAT scores are not required for admission.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Cognitive Science Minor focuses on the interdisciplinary study of the mind, drawing from fields such as psychology, computer science, philosophy, linguistics, and neuroscience. It explores the nature of intelligence, perception, memory, language, reasoning, and consciousness from multiple perspectives. This minor prepares students for graduate study or careers in fields like artificial intelligence, human-computer interaction, data science, and cognitive neuroscience.

EnglishScore: International applicants whose native language is not English must provide evidence of English language proficiency. Minimum scores for admission to a graduate degree program: TOEFL iBT: 79 (with minimum subscores of 17 for writing and 17 for speaking), IELTS: 6.5 (with minimum subscores of 5.5 in each section), Duolingo English Test (DET): 110, Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic: 53, ELS: Level 112 with a GPA of 3.0 or higher.
Department: College of Arts & Humanities
Description: The Master of Arts in Communication and Media provides advanced study in the theoretical, historical, critical, and applied dimensions of communication, media, and rhetoric. The program is designed to develop students’ analytical, research, and communication skills to prepare them for advanced graduate study, teaching, or professional positions in public and private organizations. Graduates are prepared for a variety of professions in fields such as communication, media, education, government, public relations, non-profit management, and consulting.

Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Communication and Media Minor is a 21-credit program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of how communication and media shape our world. Students will learn about various communication theories, media forms, and their societal impacts. This minor is suitable for students in any major who wish to enhance their communication skills and media literacy. It provides a strong foundation for careers in media, public relations, marketing, and other communication-intensive fields.

EnglishScore: All international students must provide evidence of English language proficiency. This can be met by submitting one of the following: TOEFL score of 61 iBT, IELTS score of 5.5, Duolingo English Test score of 95, PTE Academic score of 47, or completion of ELS Language Center's Level 112.
Requirements: We will consider you for regular admission if you meet one of the following: Graduate from high school or complete a GED, High School GPA: 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale), Class Rank: Top 50% or higher. Minnesota State Mankato is test-optional, meaning we do not require an ACT or SAT score for admission. However, if you have an ACT, SAT, or other test score, you are encouraged to submit it for course placement purposes. If your high school GPA is below 3.0, you may be asked to submit test scores or other information to demonstrate your potential for success in college.
Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Fees: $9,208.50/Year (Resident, based on 2023-2024 banded rate for 12-18 credits per semester)
Description: Students pursuing the Bachelor of Science in Earth Science will develop a strong foundation in geological processes and Earth history, as well as an understanding of the relationship between Earth science and other scientific disciplines. The program emphasizes hands-on experience through laboratory work and field trips. Students will gain skills in scientific inquiry, data analysis, and communication, preparing them for careers in environmental consulting, natural resource management, geological surveying, and education, or for graduate studies in Earth science or related fields.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies; for example, Presidential Scholar Awards range from $1,000 to $6,000

Department: College of Science, Engineering & Technology
Description: The Earth Science minor focuses on the study of the solid Earth (geology), its oceans (oceanography), and its atmosphere (meteorology). Courses for the minor examine Earth processes and materials (e.g., minerals, rocks, water, and air), Earth's history, and the evolution of life. Through completing the minor, students will learn to apply fundamental physical and chemical principles to Earth systems, evaluate Earth processes and hazards (e.g., volcanoes, earthquakes, landslides, and floods), understand sustainable use of Earth resources, and analyze the human impact on Earth systems (climate change, pollution). The minor provides a strong scientific background in Earth processes and systems. It complements a variety of majors including Biology, Chemistry, Civil Engineering, Environmental Science, Geography, Global Studies, Urban and Regional Studies, and Water Resources, and helps prepare students for careers or graduate school in earth sciences, environmental studies, and education.

EnglishScore: For non-native speakers of English, evidence of English language proficiency is required. The university accepts TOEFL iBT (minimum score 79 with subscores of 17), IELTS (minimum score 6.5 with subscores of 6.0), PTE Academic (minimum score 53 with subscores of 47), Duolingo English Test (minimum score 110), or completion of ELS Level 112.
Requirements:
In addition to the general requirements for admission to the College of Graduate Studies and Research, applicants for admission to the Master of Science program in Gender & Women's Studies must have:

A Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution.
An undergraduate cumulative grade point average of at least 3.0 on a 4.0 scale.
A statement of purpose (approximately 500-700 words) describing the applicant's background and preparation for graduate study in Gender and Women's Studies and an explanation of the applicant's purpose in undertaking graduate studies, including career and professional goals.
A writing sample (e.g., a paper written for an undergraduate course) that demonstrates the applicant's ability to engage in academic writing and critical analysis. The paper should be a minimum of five pages (double-spaced).
Three letters of recommendation submitted through the online application system that speak to the applicant's ability to succeed in graduate school.
A resume or curriculum vitae (CV).
The GRE is not required.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: Gender and Women’s Studies (GWS) is an interdisciplinary program offering a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.), a minor, and a certificate. GWS courses explore the social construction of gender and its intersection with other categories of analysis such as race, class, ethnicity, sexuality, nation, and ability. The program helps students understand how gender is woven into cultural practices and institutions, and how individuals are shaped by gendered social worlds. Students learn to critically analyze social relations of power and to envision, promote, and create social change through feminist and other justice-oriented frameworks. GWS is an ideal complement to any major. Students in the program develop skills in critical thinking, research, and communication that are valuable in a wide range of careers and graduate programs including education, law, social work, public policy, non-profit administration, international relations, health care, and business.

Requirements: A grade of "C" (2.0) or better is required for all courses to be counted toward the minor.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Latin American Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive knowledge of the region and its people. Students will examine the historical, political, economic, social, and cultural aspects of Latin America. The minor is flexible, allowing students to tailor their studies to their specific interests.

Department: College of Science, Engineering and Technology
Description: This minor introduces students to the core concepts of networking and information security. Students will learn about network infrastructure, protocols, operating systems, and security principles. Topics include network design, configuration, troubleshooting, risk management, and ethical hacking. The minor prepares students for entry-level positions in network administration and cybersecurity, or for further study in related fields.

EnglishScore: Proof of English proficiency is required for students whose native language is not English. This can be met with one of the following: a minimum TOEFL iBT score of 61, a minimum Academic IELTS score of 5.5, a minimum Duolingo English Test (DET) score of 95, a minimum Pearson Test of English (PTE) score of 47, or successful completion of ELS Language Centers Level 112.
Requirements: Minnesota State Mankato practices holistic review, which means we will look at more than just your GPA and test scores. We'll also consider your high school coursework and other information you provide on your application. For assured admission, you must meet one of the following criteria: Rank in the top 50% of your high school class, OR achieve a 3.0 GPA or higher (on a 4.0 scale), OR have an ACT composite score of 21 or higher OR an SAT total score of 1060 or higher.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: Philosophy majors develop analytical, critical, and communicative skills relevant to a wide variety of careers and graduate programs. Philosophers learn how to formulate, develop, and defend arguments concerning fundamental issues, such as the nature of reality, knowledge, and value. The Philosophy program offers courses in such areas as metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, logic, social and political philosophy, aesthetics, and the history of philosophy. Our graduates have pursued careers in law, public policy, medicine, journalism, education, ministry, social work, business, information technology, government, and other fields requiring rigorous critical thinking. Many of our majors also pursue graduate study in philosophy and other fields.

Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Scandinavian Studies minor offers students the opportunity to learn about the languages, literatures, histories, and cultures of the Scandinavian countries (Denmark, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden) and Finland. Students are introduced to the field by taking an interdisciplinary course covering central aspects of Scandinavian culture and society. In addition, they gain knowledge of a specific aspect of the region that aligns with their interests, whether it be literature, history, politics, or art. Students are strongly encouraged to combine the minor with a study abroad experience in a Scandinavian country. The Scandinavian Studies minor is beneficial to students pursuing a wide range of majors, including Anthropology, Art, English, History, International Business, International Relations, Mass Media, Political Science, Psychology, and Sociology.

Requirements:
The Scandinavian Studies Minor is an 18-credit interdisciplinary program focused on the study of the language, literature, culture, history, and social systems of the Nordic countries.

Required Courses (6 credits): SWED 101, 102.

Choose one course from the following (3 credits): SWED 201, 202.

Choose 9 credits from the following: ANTH 230; GEOG 335; HIST 333, 435; HUM 281W, 282W; POL 325, 425; SCAN 490.
Department: College of Humanities and Social Sciences
Description: The Scandinavian Studies Minor introduces students to the languages, cultures, histories, and societies of Denmark, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden. It is an interdisciplinary minor designed to complement a wide range of majors in the humanities, social sciences, and the arts. Courses taken for the minor will address topics such as Viking history, Scandinavian immigration to America, Nordic folklore, and contemporary Scandinavian literature, film, and politics. The Scandinavian Studies Minor also encourages students to undertake study abroad in Scandinavia (with scholarship support available through the Andrew J. and Mary C. Lindgren Scholarship for Scandinavian Studies). The minor consists of 18 credits.
